nodes.text: 21.4 The Black-Scholes Option Pricing Formula

In Nobel Prize-winning research, Professors Fischer Black and Myron Scholes derived a formula for the price of a European-style call option for a non-dividend-paying stock. The formula now serves as the basis of pricing for options contracts traded worldwide. Their formula is:
Black-Scholes Price of a Call Option on a Non-Dividend-Paying Stock

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mtext>Call Price</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>Stock Price</mtext><mo>×</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>−</mo><mtext mathvariant="italic">PV</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>Strike Price</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>×</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>
data.alt: Call Price equals Stock Price times upper N left parenthesis d 1 right parenthesis minus italic PV left parenthesis Strike Price right parenthesis times upper N left parenthesis d 2 right parenthesis

nodes.text: are complicated and explaining them is better left to your later finance courses.
For the curious student, they are:

data.mathML: <math alttext="" display="block" altimg="../images/mm_altmath_547.png" altimg-height="68" altimg-width="573"><mrow><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mtext>ln</mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Stock Price</mtext><mo>/</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>Strike Price</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>σ</mi><msqrt><mi>T</mi></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>σ</mi><msqrt><mi>T</mi></msqrt></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>and </mtext><mi>d</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>σ</mi><msqrt><mi>T</mi></msqrt><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nodes.text: where

data.mathML: <math alttext="" class="inlineequation" display="inline" altimg="../images/mm_altmath_548.png" altimg-height="12" altimg-width="13"><mi>σ</mi></math>

nodes.text: is the annual standard deviation of the stock return and
T
is the time to expiration of the option (in years). We also note that

data.mathML: <math alttext="" class="inlineequation" display="inline" altimg="../images/mm_altmath_549.png" altimg-height="21" altimg-width="41"><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>⋅</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>

nodes.text: in
refers to the cumulative normal distribution function.

However, we note here that they contain only the stock price, strike price, risk-free rate, time to expiration of the option, and volatility of the stock. Thus, Black and Scholes confirmed our discussion from the last section that these five factors are the only ones relevant to the value of an option. What is just as notable is what is
not

relevant: We do not need to know the expected return of the stock. You might wonder how it is possible to compute the value of a security such as an option that appears to depend critically on the future stock price without knowing the expected return of the stock. In fact, the expected return of the stock is already incorporated into the current stock price, and the value of the option today depends on the stock price today.
Fortunately, you do not need to understand the Black-Scholes formula to use it. There are many online option pricing calculators and even add-ins for Excel based on the formula. In
Figure 21.5
, we show one such calculator from the Options Industry Council.

metadata.caption: This option pricing calculator is based on the Black-Scholes option pricing formula. Here, we selected “European” in the “Style” box and then entered a stock price of $46, a strike price of $45, expiration in 60 days, a risk-free interest rate of 1%, annual volatility (standard deviation) of the stock return of 25%, and no dividends. The right side of the screen shows that the call value is $2.42 (and the put value is $1.35). The other outputs on the right side of the screen are called “the Greeks” because they are mostly Greek letters (vega is not a real Greek letter). Interested students can go to the Web site and click the question mark next to each Greek letter to learn its meaning.

Here, we selected “European” in the “Style” box and then entered a stock price of $46, a strike price of $45, expiration in 60 days, a risk-free interest rate of 1%, annual volatility (standard deviation) of the stock return of 25%, and no dividends. The right side of the screen shows that the call value is $2.42 (and the put value is $1.35). The other outputs on the right side of the screen are called “the Greeks” because they are mostly Greek letters (vega is not a real Greek letter). Interested students can go to the Web site and click the question mark next to each Greek letter to learn its meaning.

nodes.text: So far, we have discussed the factors affecting the prices of individual calls and puts. You may have noticed in
Figure 21.5

that the prices of both the put and call for the stock are displayed. In fact, those prices cannot move independently of each other. In the next section, we will demonstrate a powerful relation that links the price of a put to the price of a call on the same stock.
Concept Check
What factors are used in the Black-Scholes formula to price a call option?
How can the Black-Scholes formula not include the expected return on the stock?

metadata.caption: This option pricing calculator is based on the Black-Scholes option pricing formula. Here, we selected “European” in the “Style” box and then entered a stock price of $46, a strike price of $45, expiration in 60 days, a risk-free interest rate of 1%, annual volatility (standard deviation) of the stock return of 25%, and no dividends. The right side of the screen shows that the call value is $2.42 (and the put value is $1.35). The other outputs on the right side of the screen are called “the Greeks” because they are mostly Greek letters (vega is not a real Greek letter). Interested students can go to the Web site and click the question mark next to each Greek letter to learn its meaning.
